Award.AwardTitle: Spreading SEEDs: Large-Scale Dissemination of Hands-on Labs for Security Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This capacity building project seeks to addresses the lack of opportunities for students for experiential learning of Cybersecurity. Although there is no overall shortage of labs anymore, many instructors do not feel comfortable using them in their courses. This project has a potential to help many instructors to provide hands-on learning opportunities to their students. The project is based on the 30 SEED labs, which were developed and tested by the PI over the last ten years and are used by over 150 instructors from 26 countries. These labs cover a wide spectrum of security principles and they have proven to be effective in enhancing student learning. The project will also develop new labs to cover a timely topic in Cybersecurity education: security in mobile computing. The NSF's CyberCorpsÂ® SFS program funds projects that address cybersecurity education and workforce development. The Scholarship Track provides funding to award scholarships to students in cybersecurity. In return for their scholarships, recipients will work after graduation for a Federal, State, Local, or Tribal Government organization in a position related to cybersecurity for a period equal to the length of the scholarship. The Capacity Track seeks innovative proposals leading to an increase in the ability of the United States higher education enterprise to produce cybersecurity professionals.

There are two specific objectives of this project: 1) to dramatically increase the number of users of the SEED labs by organizing several summer workshops with about 30 participants each and by developing free online course modules, one for each lab, using one of the existing Massive Online Open Courses (MOOC) platforms; and 2) to develop new hands-on labs to address security of mobile devices which have introduced their unique Cybersecurity problems. The ultimate goal of this project is to make a transformative impact on academic institutions offering Cybersecurity courses. The project sets its goal to reach 700 schools, or about 15 percent of all universities and colleges in the United States. This will create a strong community that will carry the objectives of this project far beyond its expiration date. The project will also cultivate the integration of education and research in the area of mobile system security. The proposed Mobi-SEED labs are derived from the cutting-edge research projects on mobile-system security.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The key outcomes of this project are the following: new SEED labs, a textbook (two editions) for cybersecurity curricula, ten training workshops, and a startup company.

SEED Labs: This project built upon the 30+ SEED labs developed by the PI in another NSF project. During this project period, most of these labs have been improved, polished, and extensively tested. Some of them have been redesigned completely. Moreover, 12 new labs have been added. To help others adopt the SEED labs, a 400-page instructor manual was written, and a new version of the lab environment (virtual machine image) was created. Due to the effort in this project, the SEED labs are widely adopted worldwide. As of December 2019, over 1000 institutes in 65 countries are using SEED labs in their courses, including universities, colleges, and high schools. Companies are also using SEED labs for their internal training, as well as in recruitment. The number of adoptions will keep increasing in the years to come, as the PI will continue maintaining the project.

Textbook: Based on the experience obtained from this particular project and his 15 years of teaching experience, the PI has written a companion book for the SEED labs. The book, titled "Computer & Internet Security: A Hands-on Approach", is currently in its second edition. The book is quite different from the existing textbooks, with a sharp focus on integrating hands-on activities in explaining security theories and principles. The book has been adopted by over 100 universities/colleges worldwide within the first two years since its publication. This book will create a long-lasting impact on cybersecurity education.

Workshops: During the project period, the PI has organized 10 SEED workshops (2 per year). Each workshop was a 4-day training program that helped instructors gain hands-on experiences in cybersecurity. Overall, about 400 faculties attended the workshop. Most faculties are from the US, while a small number of attendees are from other countries. The workshops were highly valued by the participants, and after the workshops, most participants have incorporated the SEED labs into their curricula. The SEED workshop has gained worldwide recognition. Several countries and US institutes have shown interest in bringing the SEED workshop to their communities. Three international workshops have been held, two in South Korea, and one in Saudi Arabia.

Startup: This project has laid the foundation for the next phase of the SEED project. After being funded by the NSF for the last 18 years, the SEED project has reached a stage where it has the potential to become self-sustained. The PI has formed a startup company called "SEEDLabs Workshop, LLC", so he can grow the SEED, and turn it into a business, so more and more people can benefit from the project.
